column2: Chapter 29
column3: Chapter twenty nine

column2: The narrow room, in which they were smoking and taking refreshments, was full of noblemen.
column3: The narrow room, in which they were smoking and taking refreshments, was full of noblemen.

column2: The excitement grew more intense, and every face betrayed some uneasiness.
column3: The excitement grew more intense, and every face betrayed some uneasiness.

column2: The excitement was specially keen for the leaders of each party, who knew every detail, and had reckoned up every vote.
column3: The excitement was specially keen for the leaders of each party, who knew every detail, and had reckoned up every vote.

column2: They were the generals organizing the approaching battle.
column3: They were the generals organizing the approaching battle.

column2: The rest, like the rank and file before an engagement, though they were getting ready for the fight, sought for other distractions in the interval.
column3: The rest, like the rank and file before an engagement, though they were getting ready for the fight, sought for other distractions in the interval.

column2: Some were lunching, standing at the bar, or sitting at the table; others were walking up and down the long room, smoking cigarettes, and talking with friends whom they had not seen for a long while.
column3: Some were lunching, standing at the bar, or sitting at the table; others were walking up and down the long room, smoking cigarettes, and talking with friends whom they had not seen for a long while.

column2: Levin did not care to eat, and he was not smoking; he did not want to join his own friends, that is Sergey Ivanovitch, Stepan Arkadyevitch, Sviazhsky and the rest, because Vronsky in his equerry's uniform was standing with them in eager conversation.
column3: Levin did not care to eat, and he was not smoking; he did not want to join his own friends, that is Sergey Ivanovitch, Stepan Arkadyevitch, Sviazhsky and the rest, because Vronsky in his equerry's uniform was standing with them in eager conversation.

column2: Levin had seen him already at the meeting on the previous day, and he had studiously avoided him, not caring to greet him.
column3: Levin had seen him already at the meeting on the previous day, and he had studiously avoided him, not caring to greet him.

column2: He went to the window and sat down, scanning the groups, and listening to what was being said around him.
column3: He went to the window and sat down, scanning the groups, and listening to what was being said around him.

column2: He felt depressed, especially because everyone else was, as he saw, eager, anxious, and interested, and he alone, with an old, toothless little man with mumbling lips wearing a naval uniform, sitting beside him, had no interest in it and nothing to do.
column3: He felt depressed, especially because everyone else was, as he saw, eager, anxious, and interested, and he alone, with an old, toothless little man with mumbling lips wearing a naval uniform, sitting beside him, had no interest in it and nothing to do.

column2: He's such a blackguard!	He's such a blackguard!

column2: I have told him so, but it makes no difference. Only think of it!
column3: I have told him so, but it makes no difference. Only think of it!

column2: He couldn't collect it in three years!" he heard vigorously uttered by a round-shouldered, short, country gentleman, who had pomaded hair hanging on his embroidered collar, and new boots obviously put on for the occasion, with heels that tapped energetically as he spoke.
column3: He couldn't collect it in three years!" he heard vigorously uttered by a round shouldered, short, country gentleman, who had pomaded hair hanging on his embroidered collar, and new boots obviously put on for the occasion, with heels that tapped energetically as he spoke.

column2: Casting a displeased glance at Levin, this gentleman sharply turned his back.
column3: Casting a displeased glance at Levin, this gentleman sharply turned his back.

column2: Yes, it's a dirty business, there's no denying, a small gentleman assented in a high voice.
column3: Yes, it's a dirty business, there's no denying, a small gentleman assented in a high voice.

column2: Next, a whole crowd of country gentlemen, surrounding a stout general, hurriedly came near Levin.
column3: Next, a whole crowd of country gentlemen, surrounding a stout general, hurriedly came near Levin.

column2: These persons were unmistakably seeking a place where they could talk without being overheard.
column3: These persons were unmistakably seeking a place where they could talk without being overheard.

column2: Pawned them for drink, I expect.

column2: Damn the fellow, prince indeed!

column2: He'd better not say it, the beast!"
column3: He'd better not say it, the beast!"

column2: They take their stand on the act," was being said in another group; "the wife must be registered as noble."
column3: They take their stand on the act," was being said in another group; "the wife must be registered as noble."

column2: I speak from my heart.
column3: I speak from my heart.

column2: We're all gentlemen, aren't we?

column3: Above suspicion."

column2: Shall we go on, your excellency, _fine champagne?_

column2: Another group was following a nobleman, who was shouting something in a loud voice; it was one of the three intoxicated gentlemen.
column3: Another group was following a nobleman, who was shouting something in a loud voice; it was one of the three intoxicated gentlemen.

column2: I always advised Marya Semyonovna to let for a fair rent, for she can never save a profit, he heard a pleasant voice say.
column3: I always advised Marya Semyonovna to let for a fair rent, for she can never save a profit, he heard a pleasant voice say.

column2: The speaker was a country gentleman with gray whiskers, wearing the regimental uniform of an old general staff-officer.
column3: The speaker was a country gentleman with gray whiskers, wearing the regimental uniform of an old general staff officer.

column2: It was the very landowner Levin had met at Sviazhsky's.
column3: It was the very landowner Levin had met at Sviazhsky's.

column2: He knew him at once.
column3: He knew him at once.

column2: The landowner too stared at Levin, and they exchanged greetings.
column3: The landowner too stared at Levin, and they exchanged greetings.

column2: Very glad to see you!	Very glad to see you!

column2: To be sure!
column3: To be sure!

column2: I remember you very well.
column3: I remember you very well.

column2: Last year at our district marshal, Nikolay Ivanovitch's."
column3: Last year at our district marshal, Nikolay Ivanovitch's."

column2: Well, and how is your land doing? asked Levin.
column3: Well, and how is your land doing? asked Levin.

column2: Oh, still just the same, always at a loss, the landowner answered with a resigned smile, but with an expression of serenity and conviction that so it must be.
column3: Oh, still just the same, always at a loss, the landowner answered with a resigned smile, but with an expression of serenity and conviction that so it must be.

column2: And how do you come to be in our province? he asked. "Come to take part in our _coup d'etat?_" he said, confidently pronouncing the French words with a bad accent.
column3: And how do you come to be in our province? he asked. "Come to take part in our underscore coup d'etat?underscore" he said, confidently pronouncing the French words with a bad accent.

column2: All Russia's here--gentlemen of the bedchamber, and everything short of the ministry. He pointed to the imposing figure of Stepan Arkadyevitch in white trousers and his court uniform, walking by with a general.
column3: All Russia's here-gentlemen of the bedchamber, and everything short of the ministry. He pointed to the imposing figure of Stepan Arkadyevitch in white trousers and his court uniform, walking by with a general.

column2: I ought to own that I don't very well understand the drift of the provincial elections, said Levin.
column3: I ought to own that I don't very well understand the drift of the provincial elections, said Levin.

column2: The landowner looked at him.
column3: The landowner looked at him.

column2: Why, what is there to understand?	Why, what is there to understand?

column2: There's no meaning in it at all.
column3: There's no meaning in it at all.

column2: It's a decaying institution that goes on running only by the force of inertia.
column3: It's a decaying institution that goes on running only by the force of inertia.

column2: Just look, the very uniforms tell you that it's an assembly of justices of the peace, permanent members of the court, and so on, but not of noblemen."
column3: Just look, the very uniforms tell you that it's an assembly of justices of the peace, permanent members of the court, and so on, but not of noblemen."

column2: Then why do you come? asked Levin.
column3: Then why do you come? asked Levin.

column2: From habit, nothing else.	From habit, nothing else.

column2: Then, too, one must keep up connections.
column3: Then, too, one must keep up connections.

column2: It's a moral obligation of a sort.
column3: It's a moral obligation of a sort.

column2: And then, to tell the truth, there's one's own interests.
column3: And then, to tell the truth, there's one's own interests.

column2: My son-in-law wants to stand as a permanent member; they're not rich people, and he must be brought forward.
column3: My son in law wants to stand as a permanent member; they're not rich people, and he must be brought forward.

column2: These gentlemen, now, what do they come for?" he said, pointing to the malignant gentleman, who was talking at the high table.
column3: These gentlemen, now, what do they come for?" he said, pointing to the malignant gentleman, who was talking at the high table.

column2: That's the new generation of nobility.
column3: That's the new generation of nobility.

column2: They're proprietors of a sort, but we're the landowners.
column3: They're proprietors of a sort, but we're the landowners.

column2: As noblemen, they're cutting their own throats."
column3: As noblemen, they're cutting their own throats."

column2: But you say it's an institution that's served its time.

column2: Snetkov, now....

column2: We may be of use, or we may not, but we're the growth of a thousand years.

column2: If we're laying out a garden, planning one before the house, you know, and there you've a tree that's stood for centuries in the very spot.... Old and gnarled it may be, and yet you don't cut down the old fellow to make room for the flowerbeds, but lay out your beds so as to take advantage of the tree.

Old and gnarled it may be, and yet you don't cut down the old fellow to make room for the flowerbeds, but lay out your beds so as to take advantage of the tree.

column2: Well, and how is your land doing?
column3: Well, and how is your land doing?

column2: I make five per cent."
column3: I make five per cent."

column3: Aren't you worth something too?

column2: I'll tell you my own case.

column2: Before I took to seeing after the land, I had a salary of three hundred pounds from the service.
column3: Before I took to seeing after the land, I had a salary of three hundred pounds from the service.

column2: Now I do more work than I did in the service, and like you I get five per cent. on the land, and thank God for that.
column3: Now I do more work than I did in the service, and like you I get five per cent. on the land, and thank God for that.

column2: But one's work is thrown in for nothing."

column2: What would you have?

column2: It's habit, and one knows it's how it should be.

column2: So there'll be no one to keep it up.

column2: Here this year I've planted an orchard."

column2: I always feel there's no real balance of gain in my work on the land, and yet one does it.... It's a sort of duty one feels to the land."

column2: But I tell you what, the landowner pursued; "a neighbor of mine, a merchant, was at my place.

column2: We walked about the fields and the garden. 'No,' said he, 'Stepan Vassilievitch, everything's well looked after, but your garden's neglected.' But, as a fact, it's well kept up.

column2: But you and I must thank God if we keep what we've got and leave it to our children."
column3: But you and I must thank God if we keep what we've got and leave it to our children."

column2: You're married, I've heard? said the landowner.

column3: Yes, Levin answered, with proud satisfaction.

column2: Yes, it's rather strange, he went on.

column2: So we live without making anything, as though we were ancient vestals set to keep in a fire.
column3: So we live without making anything, as though we were ancient vestals set to keep in a fire.

column2: The landowner chuckled under his white mustaches.

column2: There are some among us, too, like our friend Nikolay Ivanovitch, or Count Vronsky, that's settled here lately, who try to carry on their husbandry as though it were a factory; but so far it leads to nothing but making away with capital on it.
column3: There are some among us, too, like our friend Nikolay Ivanovitch, or Count Vronsky, that's settled here lately, who try to carry on their husbandry as though it were a factory; but so far it leads to nothing but making away with capital on it.

column2: But why is it we don't do like the merchants?	But why is it we don't do like the merchants?

column2: Besides that's not work for a nobleman.
column3: Besides that's not work for a nobleman.

column2: And our work as noblemen isn't done here at the elections, but yonder, each in our corner.
column3: And our work as noblemen isn't done here at the elections, but yonder, each in our corner.

column2: There's a class instinct, too, of what one ought and oughtn't to do.
column3: There's a class instinct, too, of what one ought and oughtn't to do.

column2: However bad the land is, he'll work it.
column3: However bad the land is, he'll work it.

column2: At a simple loss."

column2: Just as we do, said Levin.

column2: Very, very glad to have met you, he added, seeing Sviazhsky approaching him.
column3: Very, very glad to have met you, he added, seeing Sviazhsky approaching him.

column2: And here we've met for the first time since we met at your place, said the landowner to Sviazhsky, "and we've had a good talk too."
column3: And here we've met for the first time since we met at your place, said the landowner to Sviazhsky, "and we've had a good talk too."

column2: Well, have you been attacking the new order of things? said Sviazhsky with a smile.
column3: Well, have you been attacking the new order of things? said Sviazhsky with a smile.
